The stock option process is that your manager has 10 days at the beginning of the quarter to start the stock option grant process and get it approved by specific people. If anyone doesn't approve it for any reason (sick, off, forgot), you don't get your stock grant and need to wait for the next quarter. The number of the stock options in your grant depends on the stock price of the previous quarter. The stock price has doubled in the past 3 months, so employees who didn't get their stock options grant approved in time last month will get half the number of the stock options they were promised, in addition to not receiving stock options this quarter. Because of this, a fair number of people lost dozens of thousands of dollars. When this happens, no one will let you know that you're not getting your stock options. If you ask, the company will let you know that this is the company policy and that they have planned to change the way stock option grants work. It's been one year that the stock option grants are supposed to change in 2 quarters. It's still supposed to change in 2 quarters. - Each team gets the same budget for the pay increases (percentage-wise) and the team impact and performance doesn't matter. - A lot of smart people left. There are more and more employees who don't care about making an impact. - There are more and more dumb company policies and it's getting harder to challenge them but most people don't care. It's a bit like what you would see in a bank.

review_title: Love the company but hate my current role
pros:
- Great product that is founded on Robin Hood like ethos.

- Great work-life balance as a CS associate on the ground. I literally don't have to worry about bringing work home once my shift is over, and management does not force you to do overtime work if you're not up for it.

- For a CS role that doesn't require tech skills, the entry level pay is one of the best I've had.

- Barely any office politics to navigate. When there is an issue that needs escalation, there is no finger pointing and the discussion is always about how to fix the issue first.

- Side projects are available on an application basis, so that CS agents can work with another non-CS team on improving the product based on their insights working on the ground.
cons:
- Product is expanding faster than the rate of hiring. There have been several crises that have caused customer contacts to balloon, but management have only come up with stop gap measures each time. They have not been able to come up with solutions that systemically fix the issues that cause CS agents to be overwhelmed.

- In terms of treating employees, it feels like Wise is more interested in rigidly equal treatment rather than *equitable* treatment. Leads don't seem interested in making case-by-case concessions for staff who may need more support than others, on the rationale that "if we make an exception for you, everyone else will start asking for exceptions".

- Unless you are intending to become a CS Team Lead, the career progression in CS is rubbish. Appraisals leading to pay increments are only conducted once a year after winter regardless of join date, for a mere two hundred dollars increment. Also, the leads seem more interested in keeping you in their team for as long as possible (so as to avoid frequent turnover) and don't actively look out for opportunities for you to transit to other teams unless you ask for it.

- Workforce management has a tendency of making sweeping and knee jerk changes to how CS agents work based on productivity statistics alone, without first conducting qualitative surveys to ask how we are doing.

- Outsourced CS staff are not provided with adequate backend access to solve customer cases and are merely there to repeat what is already on our FAQ pages. Often, when they escalate cases to full time staff, it's regarding angry customers who had an issue that could have been solved quickly if a full time staff had attended to the case immediately. On several occasions, we've even been asked to help attend to the outsourced staff's inbox directly because they are overwhelmed. Doesn't this defeat the purpose of hiring outsourced staff, who are there to alleviate the full time staff's load?

review_title: Good place to work for 1 or 2 years.
pros:
TransferWise has really cool working culture. The people here are nice, willing to help you out. Each and everyone takes initiative and their responsibility seriously:

1. No blaming: Whenever you make a mistake, accept it, fix it then tell everyone your lesson. No one is gonna blame you for that.
2.  Absolutely no politics: You dont exactly have a boss, more like a mentor/guide/leader and normally they act like your friend.
3. Great learning curve: The company has a startup culture, most people has to do lots of stuff on the ground, this opens opportunities to learn.
4. Direct feedback on your performance from your co-workers: Every quarter/half a year, you will get feedbacks from people you have worked with about what you have done and what need to be done.
5. Free trip to Estonia every year for company event, where all employees gather and party, have fun for 3 days.
cons:
1. Compensation is only acceptable
2. Learning curve stales after the first year, not much else to do, work becomes chores 
3. The company is growing too fast, new comers and people keeps moving between department makes it hard to have a stable team.
4. People have to define their own career path since the company is not so clear on this.

review_title: Very enjoyable with a good level of challenge
pros: Love the environment, very different from the big MNCs or traditional Asian sort of company. No micromanaging, a lot of responsibilities (don't worry it's manageable) and a lot of fun. Every day is different so work isn't boring. We have a cool office! Everyone is very helpful, if there's anything you want to know, you can just ask and the "open" attitude is real. Even when others are busy they won't be rude or anything they would arrange a separate time to teach you stuff. A really diverse office with people from all over the world, so you can learn lots about other cultures as well. Making mistakes doesn't make you a loser or criminal here, the focus is very much on understanding what went wrong and then moving on, try not to make the same mistake. If you're looking for something with a human touch, a place where there is recognition for the person you are, not just where you're from or what background you have, come and give it a try. Most of us are fun people (i think :p) Free food and drinks quite often too (;
cons: Honestly hard to find one, but for now our coffee machine isn't ready yet... but soon.. soon it will be.... perrrrrfect.

review_title: Good company culture but no so good team culture.

cons:
The team and the team lead will judge you by their impression. When you join the team, your job is to make everyone happy about you otherwise they will feedback you to higher up. Then you have to explain why you didn't make everyone happy. There's peer pressure where you can't express your thought when your opinion is not aligned with the company culture. In such occasions, people team will come to you and ask what happened? we welcome your feedback! but they aren't helping but assessing. 

Most of the leaders are from oldies, and some of them are not even suitable to lead, they merely stay longer in Transferwise. The feedback culture is a good intention but I see some cases when people use it against each other, and the team leader is not capable of handling it.

pros:

A lot of perks and benefits while working in Singapore office, i.e. team lunches and Friday drinks. Compensation is above average and you work with one of the smartest people you'll ever meet.
Opportunity to travel to Europe at least once a year on an all-hands company event.
cons:
As a newbie, you'll be thrown to the wolves (so to speak) with little  documentation to help you out.

Sometimes, it's always the person with the largest voice that is heard. It's a bit tricky to work here for introverts. Have to learn to speak your mind and be counted.

job_title: Full Stack Software Engineer in Singapore
pros: Extremely friendly people, the office team is the best I have ever seen (so many fun things are organised, delicious Friday buffet), the satisfaction of making a contribution in people's lives by helping them save money (compared to banks)
cons: The company has recently digressed a lot from its core values. It is no longer a "revolution" because there are so many companies who are doing the exact same things and they do it better. There is no sense of urgency of "getting things done" - people are focussed on turf wars, there is lots of politics going on with respect to ownership, the oldies in the company seem to think they are the powerful authorities, forming cliques amongst them - backing each other, giving promotions to their countrymen, not listening to criticisms, but overly eager to project the negative effects (arising from their behaviour) on the other members of their teams. We no longer keep customers first - we regularly increase prices to get more profit margins for the investors (but blame the increasing costs of employee salaries, which are way below market standards), we no longer are transparent to the customers, we are regressing on the speed of transfers the last few months, the product is unusable, the tech stack is unstable - but the product managers don't seem to care about them. "No drama, good karma" - literally the opposite happens. There are ego problems with the oldies and leads, they can't take negative feedback and escalate to their leads if you tell them about these, code reviews will get blocked because it is not written as per the other person's whims, leads and product managers regularly do catch-ups as part of their day jobs, but nothing concrete ever comes that improves the product for the customers or the employees' careers, leads getting away by doing only easy tasks and literally exploiting the travel and remote opportunities to the maximum for themselves. There is no autonomy anymore - please don't get fooled by the blog posts, the company is growing big and it is the leads who will be the managers and have literally unlimited control and zero accountability.

review_title: A place that practices what it preaches
pros: Ground up approach to what we work on - our team identifies our biggest issues and we work on them with top priority. Collaborative culture it feels like the vast majority of people care about making Wise work better and helping each-other. Very unexpectedly lots of travel opportunities. Great internal transparency on pay & a genuine feedback culture. Constant learning opportunities as our remit at work is so broad there are many different teams, products & initiatives to get involved in. Food at work is a great perk. Working from the office is mostly completely optional - makes it feel like a collaborative space rather than a place we are forced to go to. Senior management don't have offices, they work at the same banks of desks that everyone else does - means you can get to know them and also get a real feeling that we are all working together. Equity Bonuses make me feel invested into the success of Wise. Its very easy to genuinely believe that Wise is making the world a slightly better place & working for a company you believe in makes a huge difference.

review_title: Good office and company, poor pay and work-life balance in CS.
pros: There are many pros: Pay: The pay is good considering Hungary's economic crisis, and there are several extra benefits (szép card, 100% sick pay, long maternity and paternity leave, 30+ days off). Hiring: It is relatively easy to get hired as the company is growing very fast, and HR hires people with zero experience in the field. I think it is good that they evaluate your common sense and soft skills and don't just focus on relevant professional experience. This allows students and graduates to start a career somewhere with good pay easily. It is not too hard to grow within the company starting in CS, because they prefer to hire internally. Growth: Continuous development is the primary goal of the company, so they do not get stuck in old and useless habits, but it does mean a lot of changes almost weekly that you have to keep up with. Community: The company puts a lot of effort into community building, so you will have the chance to go to really fun team events monthly, and attend team lunches and brunches on alternating weeks, we usually have pizza and cake in the office, and they consider dietary requirements. We have Wise days and mission days, parties on boats and in private clubs, and so on. The office space itself is amazing with so many facilities. Gym, sauna, kitchens with free food, fun area, living room, lots of spacious and well-equipped desks, and more. It is quite easy to make friends, everybody is super approachable and nice, and the office culture is indeed extraordinary. Overall: If you align with the company's mission, it feels good that you know you are working towards a great goal and that your efforts are not in vain.
cons: Scheduling: The shift division is not ideal, you do not know your shift until like 4 days before the next month starts, so it is tough to plan your personal life around it. You can be scheduled for any time, sometimes starting at 7 am, sometimes finishing at 11 pm (but the company does consider if you are a student or parent, though they don't consider anyone entirely in between. You will have to do weekend shifts. With the new scheduling system, you will have to be doing phones for 5.5 hours a day- and Wise gets an insane amount of complaints and angry customers, so it is emotionally draining. Crisis handling: There is a new crisis or incident every second week and management acts like it's the first time something like that happens, so the customers do not get a solution to their issue for days or sometimes weeks. Of course, the customer support agents left in the dark become the punching bag of the angry customers. Once a customer complained that working with Wise feels like working with a bunch of college dropouts, and that pretty much summarises it - many of us are college dropouts. Pay: The other employees in the Estonian office earn 1.5-2 times more (in euros) for the same hours in the same role than the Hungarian team, and that is because the company is profiting from the insane inflation in Hungary. They have literally admitted to this. You basically have to fight and beg for a ridiculously small benchmarking raise. The work: The role involves so much more than just regular CS. You have to do the complaint handling (several a month), you do all the escalations to other teams ( you have to figure out who to escalate to, which is usually not evident), and you will be scheduled t give extra training the new agents because they receive 3 weeks of training, but there is so much knowledge to learn that most people don't get into the flow until 3-4 months in. Overall: The cons are many and sound bad, but they are kind of part of working in CS, and may not be worse than at other similar companies.

review_title: Huge (negative) CS changes in the last few months
pros: Wise used to be an amazing company to work for. I've been there over a year, and I used to believe the role was a dream come true - hard, but the benefits and work/life balance were worth it. Wise made a big deal about valuing employee mental health, so they limited the amount of time agents spent on the phone, which made it feel different from any other call center positions around. Schedules and shifts were consistent as well. You had weekends off, except for one day a month, which made spending time with family easy.
cons: In the past few months, Wise has made sweeping changes to the Customer Service role. Agents are now on phones the majority of their time. Schedules have moved to a shift bidding system that has been broken since it launched, resulting in agents having weird and inconsistent schedules (i.e. Mon 12-8, Tue 8-4, Wed 12-8, Thurs 9-5, Fri 8-4). You are also required to work two full weekends a month now. Because of the broken shift bidding system requiring manual corrections by Workforce Management, you won't receive your schedule for the month until a couple of days before it starts, so good luck planning appointments and life events! Managers (called Team Leads at Wise) takes constant long lunches or walk around in packs joking with each other, while agents are stuck unsupported on the floor. If you ever reach out for help from a manager, you're told they're busy and to lean on other CS agents for help. Meanwhile, you can see them sipping coffee and laughing with a group of other team leads from where you're sitting. By the way, there's a tiny parking lot at the Tampa location, so you will be forced to pay $20-$25 for parking at a local lot unless you want to try to get there early enough to secure a spot for yourself.

After working at 4 different substantial companies in the past, this is the first time I'm actually proud working for a company. People have high EQ, are overall smart and inclusive, and are encouraged and informed to be so based on merit. People are not just seen as expendable working bees here, for the most part.

The workday involves structure, clarity and respect for autonomy, which in this case also leads to superior results. In that, Wise is also very friendly towards people who are independent thinkers or neurodivergent. 

The company actually does succeed in preventing workplace stress that's not strictly work related, e.g. bullying etc. High-functioning autistic and people with ADHD traits would not find a much better-suited environment.

Lastly, the product and the way of building it is great. Every team and function is appreciated and is given a slice of the larger pie with stock options. So we could own our work and actually be a part of the company. 

And that is the best thing ever.
cons:
It can be challenging to understand the flat hierarchy and to meet ever-growing expectations. With the latter, the goal is constant improvement, though it can be a bit daunting and challenging, especially at first.

Only thing I would ideally love to see more is the option of part-time work. It is generally an option here, but 4-day work weeks could actually be better for some people, also in terms of overall output.

pros:
If you are not working an operational team, you'll be fine. 
They have great benefits, events, free food, and all that in the office. 

The pay is also great, you'll get a raise every year or so if you work well.
cons:
The company presents itself as so people friendly, and such a progressive workplace. Well, its like that for some people only. Working at this company means no work-life balance, no rest and a constant grind. 

Wise mistreats its CS associates, and many operational workers. 

CS associates are not allowed on holidays when they would want or need it. There is a strict schedule and on some locations only 2 people can be on holidays at once. 

Because of this everyone is burnt out and overworked. They even ask us to come in during the weekend for no extra pay (some rare occasions you'll get some extra pay). You'll have to do weekends at this company for sure no matter which team you are working at. 

Upper management gets paid pretty well, so they don't really care about what the rest of the team gets, or about their working circumstances. 

The work is monitored, every hour you have to bring certain numbers, if not, you are put on a temporary probation. If you fail that, you'll be put on probation. We all know what comes after that. 

Management has to present you every quarter with stats, no matter how hard you work, its just never going to be enough, the stats can always be raised, you should always do more.

Due to this the fluctuation is insane, you rarely work with the same people for more than 6 months.

I know many people who's anxiety worsened, or they have gotten depressed while working at wise. I have never had anxiety before, and now its crippling. When trying to ask for help they gaslit me, and told me that I should try different methods for stress relief outside of work.

This means it doesn't feel like fighting an uphill battle all the time, which is a huge relief for Compliance people and not all that common (especially at FinTechs).

I have a feeling this is a really stellar place to work if you're earlier in your career, you would get a lot of experience and chances to learn and develop.

Wise pay far below market rates for experienced staff.

Autonomous teams/complex structure can make things tricky to navigate.

The focus on cost avoidance is very high, which I would argue is a detriment to the other values (especially convenience). Would personally advocate for rethinking the customer service model, since while self-service should be the goal, having such little support for customers available when things do go wrong for them (long SLA's, difficult to contact support teams, lack of clear escalation and ownership of various customer facing issues) makes us a really quite bad experience for a substantial number of customers.

Still an awesome company, but the cons make it a poor fit for me and seemingly a fair number of others, as turnover seems a bit high even by start-up standards.

review_title: A pony disguised as a unicorn
pros:
- Looks great on my CV
- Stock options
- Home office
cons:
- The annual salary raise didn't happen in the Spring of 2020 due to Covid, we were told it's a precaution. While we accepted this, we then had to listen to a dozen meetings/updates about our growth, how Wise did well, how we're making better than good money, how grateful leadership is to "Wisers" and how management is opening a new, physical office in Singapore (say what now?). But of course, our annual salary review was postponed over and over again. We literally had to fight for it, and in the end they told us that we made good enouh money already, we didn't need a raise. We kept pushing it however, arguing for at least compensation for inflation. After almost a year of waiting and fighting, they agreed to give us a 10% raise for the inflation. But during the process we were told that we're ungrateful ("you should be happy you have a job") while also listening to the corporate propaganda of us "being one big happy family." Yeah, right.

- Benefits are minimal. When I joined, it was more (but still modest compared to other actors in the field): diverse breakfast in the morning, generous stock options, monthly pass for public transport. Then they took them away one by one, leaving us with literally nothing, and a slim stock option package for new joiners. In the middle of the pandemic, not only did I not receive any of the above benefits, Wise diverted its own costs at the employees by not giving any subsidy for home office. Oh wait, they did: a one-time 25K HUF (80 USD) allowance to buy ourselves a chair or something, and this was rubbed in our faces over and over again as a token of their generosity.

- Three time's the charm, so let me add one more to this happy family/taking you for an idiot streak. Benefits are not given at Wise, because of the stock options. Then Wise enters the stock market: the founders are now billionaires, the employees are happy too that they may be able to buy themselves a car, maybe even a flat. And then the co-founder sells the majority of his shares (he wasn't a billionaire enough I guess) causing the share price tumbling. Thanks to him, many of us had to say goodbye to bigger purchases as the stock prices haven't recovered at all. But I guess he can buy himself a second gold plated shark tank bar by the pool. It's also "wise" that Wise provides benefits in this highly volatile currency: stocks.

- Other than the ones above here are some honorary mentions for cons: sweeping sexual harrasment cases under the rug; toxic positivity; microagression; lack of career path; lack of development options; nepotism; flat out lying (as others have also mentioned, though I'd add it's not only around firings but promotions too). 

I guess if you have to be a wageslave, working at Wise is not the worst option. But don't have any illusions, it's just another job to pay the bills and feed the kids.

After having spent over €2,103 on flights, hotel, feeding, visa fee, appeal fee etc.

The recruiter contacted me and told me they had no choice but to rescind the job offer.

And that was it. Just like that.

Since I had already resigned from my previous job offer after accepting a job offer from Wise, now being jobless in my home country, I had to start looking for a job all over again.

Most importantly, the company's mission is centred around benefiting customers through promoting fair and transparent pricing for cross-currency transactions, contrary to traditional banks. Additionally, the whole company is focused on growing the business and reducing costs so savings can be passed to customers in the form of lower prices. It genuinely makes you feel great to show up to work every day knowing that your input is making a difference to people's lives - £1bn annual savings in FX fees to be precise! 

Flexible working arrangements, focus on employee well-being and and supporting environment.

Numerous opportunities for learning and development. Many colleagues have moved into other roles either within the Tribe or other teams as internal mobility is actively encouraged.
cons:
Fast-paced environment with frequent new products and projects, which I assume is not for everyone.

Each team has a quarterly planning process based on the Objective & Key Result framework which takes some time to get used to if you do not have any previous experience.

review_title: Lots of promises of autonomy and hope, but ultimately a big disappointment with lots of lip service.
pros:
Work at home
Money is ok
Fellow employees seem nice and helpful
cons:
Wasn’t honest on a variety of things, including scheduling, and helping you to succeed.

I started out having a great interview where I seemed to mix it up well with my manager. After being offered the position we went through 5 weeks of training that was all initiated over Zoom.
I was one among maybe 10 new hires that worked a 9-5 Mon- Fri shift. Training was broken up each week by a new group of trainers that used PowerPoints for the majority of training. The training was arduous. It’s a banking job so there was hours upon hours of policies and procedures. Every other day we took a 10 question assessment, and each Friday we took a end of week wrap-up test. Trainers emphasized to all of us several times not to stress out on the assessments , to just do your best. If you failed a weekly quiz you could retake it until you passed. 

The material was dense, and overwhelming at times. Trying to stay focused after hours of procedural training was a battle of attrition.  I got along w my teammates really well and their camaraderie made the stress of learning all the material go by quickly.

After about 3 weeks our group separated into their respective roles with their managers and  new teams. From here I started to get more personalized training from my manager and team directly. We had a end of week assessment (the most difficult to date) and I needed a 80% to pass and only scored a 77%. I was told several different times that this was normal and that I would have the rest of the week to go over the material I got wrong and retake the test. 
Believing that they had my interests in mind I relaxed my nerves and studied. When I took the  test again I scored a 100%, I knew the material that I had missed earlier inside and out. Later in the day my manager emailed me telling me to join him in a zoom room with his manager to discuss the test. It Seemed that my bosses manager didn’t want me retaking the test where the questions were the same as my last test (which was odd because this has been the structure through all 5 weeks of training). 

I was told verbatim “we’re going to give you a new test w different questions and you’ll have 2 hours to complete it, but don’t let it stress you out...even if you fail it we’ll get you the proper help you need...so no worries....you won’t get fired for failing a quiz”. 

So I was given a new test with all essay questions (all prior tests were multiple choice), and I did the best I could not being able to study any specific areas ahead of time. I received a 65% on my first attempt on the new test. Upset I emailed my manager and said “I’m feeling a lot of pressure w these assessments considering how I studied for and passed the last one only for it to be thrown out and a new test administered that I didn’t prepare for. My manager responded telling me that it’s ok, and he’ll get w his manager to discuss a game plan for the future so that I’m comfortable moving forward...mind you by this time I was in week 5 and actively working cases and sending emails and communicating w clients.

The next morning I was called into a zoom room with both managers plus an HR rep. My manager asked if my day was going well and I responded yes....then his manager briefly went over some of the questions I got wrong on my last test. Once she finished w/o missing a beat the HR rep said “we’re going to have to part ways with you, you’re not a good fit for the company right now “. Needless to say I was shocked, and assessing the tone of the meeting they had already made up their minds even after saying all trainers and employees I worked with had nothing but good things to say about me, they didn’t want to engage in any type of discussion. 

So my advice to anyone whose hired: take what they tell you w a grain of salt. I was told the assessments wouldn’t get you fired (several times)...that was a lie. I was told that I would be getting a permanent 9-5 shift
Mon-Friday....that was a lie, as soon as my training w my actual team started they said I’ll have late night shifts and work weekend days.
I was told emphatically how they’re here for you and your personal development, and offer a multitude of support....that was a lie. I left a company I had a job with and was secure in ....believing that I would have at least an opportunity to prove myself at Wise, only to be turned away after 5 weeks because I wasn’t a “good fit”?

review_title: Mediocre CS role at just another corporation (with nepotism here and there)
pros:
I would probably give 4 stars when I started 3 years ago, but the longer I stay in the company the more disillusioned I become. Not many pros left due to the current world situation, but I will try to list a few that’s left:
-	Average salary – 1300 EUR. You will get 100 EUR raise each year if you are sane enough to stay longer and comply with constantly increasing performance requirements. 
-	30 EUR allowance per month for gym / sports
-	Few dozens of stock options (if you are starting in 2021 – you probably won’t get anything, forget it)
-	Most customers are nice which means that you won’t be yelled at for entire 8 hours each day. Just a couple of angry customers who may drain your soul, but that’s ok compared to other CS jobs.
cons:
-	You are in CS. This means other teams treat you like you are at the bottom of the food chain. Nobody cares about the work you do, except your team lead. He, or most likely she (80% of CS team leads are women), will pretend they care. Back in the days they used to have 10 phone hours per month to help customers, now they don't even touch communications with clients. Team leads spend their days "planning" the future and thinking how to make you more efficient. If you received a manger call – you have to spend ages finding another CS agent who will pretend to be a manager.

-	Career progression is unlikely, unless you are one of cool kids or formed a friendship with a hiring manager. It doesn’t matter how many years you’ve worked in the company. All depends on whether a team lead likes you and whether they hear things they want to hear during an interview. I’ve seen really talented people not getting a job they’ve done tremendous amount of work for – that’s normal when it comes to CS in TransferWise. Wrong people get promoted for no reason. Also, most non-CS positions are opened to external hiring. Oh, and if your team lead feels you are not performing as well as you should be, you will not get a permission to apply anywhere.

-	Toxic "feedback culture". A lot of people in the company don’t know how to give feedback and how to receive it. Even if you did something that wasn’t your fault, I recommend to say “thank you” and suck it up. Don’t give a feedback to your team lead – most of them have a big ego and you will regret it at some stage.

-	Performance requirements constantly changing. One month you may find yourself doing a good job, the next month your team lead is telling you it is not enough because it is based on some new “smart” metric.

-	Interviews for internal applications for other positions are often done by amateurs who are not really interested in you as a candidate. pros:
- You get a lot of responsibility which makes you learn a lot quick
- There is no (micro)management at all. People trust you entirely in your job.
- Work hours and location are very flexible (even before COVID). Nobody cares if you come in late, or leave early from time to time. It's mainly about your results, people don't mind how you achieve them.

cons:
- The autonomous culture is great: you look for your own projects and work on what you think is important. I personally liked it, but for some people this might be confusing and hard.
- The organization is very flat: there's almost no hierarchy. This means you get a lot of decision making power and freedom. But this also means that there is no real way to develop a 'career' within TransferWise. You can only really become a team lead, which is only possible if your lead leaves. Beyond that there's no way to 'climb up the ladder'. The CEO himself said that he 'doesn't want people to come to TransferWise to develop careers'.

pros: salary is above average customer service money
cons:
was treated like garbage, it is all wrong

You arrive and being treated with direct, apparent kindness and helping care for the onboarding week. Do not believe it. They will show you the table soccer, pool table, workout room... You will never have a minute to use any of them, these are just for show-off. All sorts of free food in the office, once a week company lunch, breakfast, coffee, coke products and fruit are free every day. Until you have COVID and this all goes to nil, you work from home office, you get NOTHING, no perks, no transport pass, no cafeteria. You are being closely watched all the time, especially by your team lead. The team leads are generally twenty-something year old young girlscouts, who might be well versed in technical knowledge valid only if you work there, but absolutely incapable of humanely carry the role of leading people and dealing with real persons, especially of older ages. They will never protect you, or curious about your side of the story, but will help telling you off and discipline you for out-of-the-team claims. Team leads have the tendency to pick and promote freshly hired girls to team lead level, those with whom they find appealing. If someone is not promoted by the end of their probation, then probably he/she will remain in the same position forever. Do not worry, this does not last a long time. Some people are put to personal improvement plan (PIP), which means they are basically looking for a good reason to fire the person. Sometimes it follows probation time right away, and as the PIP includes the option to be fired for underachievement if the desired results are not reached. The desired level is calculated by having tickets reviewed by the same scoutgirls, who do what their girlfriend team leads ask of them, and 85% is the pass rate. You can fail a ticket for simply not writing it in the manner the reviewer thinks it should have been written, and also for not filling in a statistics category for a ticket the way the reviewer thinks it should have been. During the PIP session, which lasts a short two months, you are heavily micromanaged, they know about your idle time, the time you spend with a customer, the time you spend by writing scripts about customer calls, what you do on the company laptop, EVERYTHING. As you are on PIP, it is like probation time never ends, you are being threatened to be fired constantly. The most stressful and disgusting part is when they tell you how everyone only wants to help you only (utter lie) they tell you they have a feedback culture, so feedback has to be received and given as HELP (even bigger lie). However, if you try to make a remark of criticizm, you will realize that the feedback culture is a one way street, you should welcome it but should not practice it. Everyone at the company is at a higher rank than customer agents. They claim there are no managers, as there is a flat company structure, but this is just another major lie, everyone is your superior at any team, and you are treated by most accordingly. YOu turn for help to one of the currency management teams, and all you get is public shaming, then when you retort, you get a warning. This time it is not your feedback anymore, but you have 'communication problems'. They say there is no lunchtime, so you spend eight hours working and that is it, lunchtime is included. This is a lie, as lunchtime is there if you can manage to perfom the required number of tickets and still have ten minutes to eat something. I have never given wrong information to any customer and had lots of thank you letters from grateful people, but this is not what Transferwise, and especially the team lead girlscouts want. The job itself can be done OK, although it is VERY stressful, I never felt so tired in my whole life. TransferWise was a HORRIBLE experience, with daily practiced hypocrisy, a little bit like when we had to pretend we believe in communism, where you were forced to show the belief of their lies and get ashamed and humiliated by a 20 year old team lead girl on a daily basis until she manages to get you fired for not performing above 85% constantly. The expected number of tickets per hour were harshly increased in 6 months, it was raise from 5 to 6 in an hour (definitely no time to get lunch or do a number two) and even the task of removing sensitive customer data from emails was assigned as an extra task, which equals with about the time of finishing a ticket in an hour. If you miss removing the data (like phone numbers) then the ticket fail the review. To top it all, your team lead talks to you about your upcoming sacking as if it was 'unfortunately' an event like losing an entrance test for a TV quiz. No, damn it, this is about putting me to the street in the middle of the pandemic - while they kept hiring newcomers. At times there were not enough tickets to work on, but nobody really cared or tried to help you. I would not recommend working here to my worst enemy, unless you are a 20 year old girl with the soul, experience and attitude of a Japanese cartoon character.

review_title: Changing into a corporation - confusing and lacking in communication
pros:
I am really struggling in finding Pros to talk about since everything I want to say is very generic to any other company. 
Pros: 
- Free office food like cereal
- Great chill-out areas for breaks
- The "culture" is very warm and often makes you proud to work there
- Not a typical call-centre yet.
- Co-workers are often friendly and brilliant.
cons:
- The "culture" is fake for a lack of a better word. There are people in the company that try very hard to make you feel good about working there but it is constantly overshadowed by the slow transition of becoming a corporation. One side wants you to be autonomous and be your own boss, everyone is free to choose their own path; whereas the management side is very strict in what you do, when you do it and how you do it. Creates a lot of mis-communication and lack of communication, where performance reviews might come as a surprise.
- Customer Support positions are NOT only customer support positions - you have a chance to get/ask for extra responsibilities in the form of a side project. Why this is a con is because you are still evaluated as a Customer Support Agent and the extra responsibilities are in no way looked at when it comes down to your performance. The management does not understand what the employee actually does and they try to evaluate your work based on one single number. These extra responsibilities and the work you do might mean a lot for the company but again, if you ain't hitting that performance target that all Customer Support agents need to hit, then your contributions elsewhere are not taken into consideration.
- These extra responsibilities can be actual positions in other companies but with TransferWise you still get the same pay as any other customer support agent. There are no bonuses for doing more than 100%, or for doing other extra work on the side for them.
- No communication around the performance target that you need to hit. I had asked multiple times on how this target was calculated and I did not receive any proper analysis or work around it. I wasn't even sure if this performance target was possible to achieve for every single customer support agent based on the workload. There are company wide meetings to specifically talk about decisions made by senior management but again, they typically dance around specific subjects.
- Stock options as benefits - wonderful idea as a start-up where you can start your own career. Bad idea for a corporation that has a high employee turnover, which seems to be the direction for Transferwise.

job_title: Head of Team in London, England
pros:
TransferWise lives up to the hype. It's a unique chance to learn and make an impact in a business which is genuinely setting new standards in financial services. A few things that stand out for me:

- The people are smart, decent, and there's a sense that doing the right thing is important in all aspects of the business. When People issues do crop up, they're taken seriously
- Everyone is obsessed with the TransferWise mission from product through to CS. This helps unite the global team, and means the biz is focused on building good quality payments rails 'under the bonnet' of the product. Downside is the buzzy front end features other fintechs churn out take longer at TransferWise, because the team is more focused on incremental changes to making transfers faster, cheaper etc. Long term I think this investment is worth it
- Most teams have clear structures for career development. Progression is based on merit, and in my experience hard work is rewarded
- In most cases there is room to try new things and fail, as long as you demonstrate learnings
- Everyone in the business is awarded share options, even at entry level
- The founders and senior leadership team are hard working and committed to the mission 9 years on from the company being founded
- It's a fun place to be! Annual company holiday, travel for most roles, typical beer and pizza style start-up parties. Lots of people relocate from overseas for TransferWise and make close friendships in the company
cons:
- It's not for everyone. The autonomous teams model requires you to be entrepreneurial to get things done. If you're not a self-starter you will find it hard to navigate the blockers inherent in the company's structure
- There's a strong feedback culture which can get pretty noisy and be disheartening. It's a blessing and a curse, the right level of feedback leads to positive outcomes, other times it's overwhelming, unproductive and paralyses the people with the most expertise from doing their jobs
- The company has some work to do on Diversity & Inclusion at leadership level. It's making up for this now but it could have been looked at sooner

review_title: Challenging, rewarding, exciting, open and creative in equal measure.
pros:
TransferWise lives and dies by it's mission to save people from unfair financial practice by their banks, particularly as it relates to transferring money abroad. I'm typically a skeptical person in this area, but have been so impressed with how this mission and our values drive us forward.

There's a tremendous amount of opportunity to explore things that you're interested in. Teams operate somewhat autonomously from the rest of the company, and decide on the initiatives that are most likely to move their KPIs forward. This means you can decide your own plans, act and deliver on things that you're passionate about.

TransferWise operates out of offices in nine different countries, and genuinely encourage employees to travel when it makes sense for your role. You'll have a great chance to see the world with TransferWise, and play an important role on shaping it through the work you do.
cons: The idea of autonomous teams is struggling to scale as we do. What was a great idea when we were smaller, is causing information and knowledge silos that are starting to bottleneck our ability to grow quickly. Teams are struggling to work cohesively with other teams when their priorities and objectives don't necessarily match up.

pros:
If you're someone that thrives on opportunity to be ambitious, try things and have some autonomy around how you and your team make decisions, TransferWise is perfect. It's fast paced, customer-centric and really pushes you to evolve yourself into someone that can make tough decisions as well as giving and receiving honest feedback. 

There are over 65 nationalities working at TransferWise, with people from all sorts of backgrounds, cultures and countries, which means that we're all passionate about the product we're building, and bring new perspectives to the table. 

There's a general understanding that people have lives outside of work - whether that be friendships, families, pets. Teams are supportive and flexible in that respect, with the trust that the impact will be made. It's up to individuals to be responsible for that.
cons:
If you're used to being told what to do and can't work through decisions yourself - you'll struggle. 

Progression isn't 'linear' in the sense that - you do this thing, jump through this hoop, you'll get a promotion. For me that's actually a pro as you're incentivised to learn and broaden your skillset for real purpose rather than for an artificial goal. However we are still in the point of our company life where we are relatively unstructured about people's development and need to spend more time on this to support people during TransferWise and for life after.

pros:
TransferWise is a standout company to work for; especially in comparison to may U.S. employers. Not only is it a relaxed working environment with hardworking, smart, and incredibly fun people, but the benefits are amazing. PTO (vacation and sick time) is very generous, maternity leave is actually offered, there are paid travel opportunities, sabbatical after 4 years, medical/dental at great rates, and many other available benefits.

Additionally, unlike many places which claim there's room to grow with the company but actually make it very difficult to move about, TransferWise delivers on this promise. If you're interested in a particular project or position, you're supported and encouraged to get involved with a side-projects alongside you current role, or pursue available role(s) that interests you. I've seen many people switch roles within 6 months-1 year, and even seen new positions be born out of someone's success with their side-project.
cons:
Not necessarily a con (in my mind), but something to be aware of that some people may consider a con: this is still very much a startup culture; there's times where processes aren't full fleshed out, and things need to be changed as we grow and adapt to new circumstances. If you're a person who needs strict/unchanging policies and procedures, then this probably isn't the place for you. This isn't your typical corporate environment, so it's best not to come in expecting this. 

There is room for improvement in starting salaries for most of the lower level positions. However, I definitely respect that they are extremely transparent with starting salaries for most positions on offer.

review_title: The best company in Estonia to work for!
pros:
Great career opportunities if you are hard working and can find your own path. 

Amazing work environment - everybody in the team is customer focused and people are always up for collaboration in order to make the customers lives easier. 

Stock options - A great way for employees to be invested in the company.

Autonomous teams - It's kind of a double edged sword. When the team lead is good at their job the autonomous team is a super efficient way to work, but unfortunately due to our amazing growth some teams are unorganized due to the autonomous teams and could use a better lead. 

You can bring your pet to work!
cons:
The salary is still not the best when compared to the market, e.g in banking.  
Especially when taking into account the average salary rise within the last year and the consumer price index.

Sometimes it does feel like older employees get better benefits for the same job. E.g better salaries, oldies protect each other and new positions are given to older employees even when someone else could be a better fit. 

More assistance could be offered to team members by the team leads in order to find the career path they are interested in. Not everybody can build their own path 100% and it's completely fine :) 

But these are just small things to improve on and overall the pros outweigh the cons massively.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to be part of the new and innovative world
pros: Really good company - takes care of you. The fully paid health days, flexible working hours, understanding and human approach to personal and work-related development. Fun activities in the form of the company Days (Summer and Winter Days) - basically a fully paid vacation in beautiful Estonia. Young and dynamic team, perky and not too geeky, despite being a technology firm. Personal development within the company encouraged and your participation in improvements is not only encouraged but even expected. Oh, NO DRAMA GOOD KARMA, one of our basic values is very much kept. Also, you can always pretty much freely choose, what side project you want to work on, and you're given free hands and even help, if you are working towards helping the customer.
cons: We have grown very fast and some growing pains, like not always having the most appropriate people in place and sometimes miscommunication of some stuff, are in place. We are starting to lose some of the start-up culture we had back then and sometimes you can (sadly) feel the gap between the old-timers and newbies. Also, some job definitions or positions are not clearly defined, leaving room for uncertainty in terms of responsibilities, rights, and how much they could/should earn.

pros:
- Character is placed at a higher priority than experience. People with a positive attitude and a genuine desire to contribute to something greater than themselves are hired over others that perhaps have more experience or skill but aren't interested in team, helping customers or learning new things. 

- Because only trustworthy people are brought on board, employees are afforded lots of freedom and autonomy over their schedules and work places. 

- Lovely, bright offices with lots of happy, kind people 

- Lots of internal hiring and chances to move to different teams. In many cases, it's better for the company to teach a seasoned TransferWise employee a new skill than to teach a new hire with lots of skill everything that is TransferWise (not an easy or short task). 

- There isn't really a management hierarchy, but TransferWise 'team leads' are the best 'managers' a person could ask for - always trusting, helpful, flexible and fair. They want what's best for you.
cons:
- Intense. Lots and lots to learn and very challenging work. Can be overwhelming and/or exhausting. 

- Could be considered a 'Pro', but lots of shift work. Often times it's necessary to work evenings/nights/weekends or early in the morning. This being said, it's usually possible to mold your schedule around your preferences.

review_title: Good Company...But Happy To Be Out!
pros:
international travel 
mission driven startup 
great and smart employees

Bad management. TransferWise has given all of the top opportunities to the wrong people. Ones who have been with the company since it's early days but really have no idea what they are doing. Leadership and management are threatened by scrappy smart colleagues and will do anything to push them out and have them get fired. 

I was fired and was one of the top performing individuals in the marketing department. All because my boss didn't like me as a person after being initially obsessed with me in the interview/early months of me being there. 

Major turnover in the NYC and London offices. 

Experienced sexual harassment during Summer Days. Reported it and nothing happened or was addressed. 

Racist CEO and leadership team from Eastern Europe who have never seen black, gay or any diverse people in their life. 

LOW SALARY. Get with the times - this isn't a nonprofit, so stop acting like it.

pros: Very supportive team members, can go to anyone for help

review_title: Many opportunities, but chaotic. Tension between Tallinn and London.

pros:
- The mission. It's great to do something that has a bigger meaning. We are all here to change the world of finance.

- The team. We are inspired by working in a united, caring and multicultural team. Wisers are massively talented and motivated, not to mention some of the friendliest and kindest people you will meet. 

- The freedom & trust. In TransferWise I have a lot of freedom in my work. My lead isn't telling me what I should work on, but he is there for me when I want to bounce ideas and supports me when I need it. Sometimes this freedom & responsibility is scary, but it helps me to grow. 

- Personal growth. During my TransferWise journey (more than three years) I have worked on so many different topics and learned a lot while doing it. As we grow so fast, we have all the time new challenges coming up, and I have crossed my comfort zone limits so many times.

- Great vibe. The overall atmosphere is very relaxed and non-stressful but still professional. We also have super cool offices & healthy breakfast
cons:
- As our teams are autonomous, there can be problems with communications and it has happened that two teams are working on similar things

- Having so much freedom and responsibility can be overwhelming. You need to pay a lot of attention to your well-being.

pros:

Strong value-based mission
Small teams, more autonomy 
chances of growth
cons: Not really a con, but work life is fast paced

pros: Transferwise is really committed to making the values work on the day to day. Apart from that, the culture is amazing, the growth is very high and the C-Level (if we can even call it that) is super down to earth.
cons: With the autonomous teams, there also comes a few challenges such as structuring the teams, making operational teams efficient and aligning everyone. Since I got here it's been very confusing in terms of what the salary brackets are, when to trigger these promotions and what I should be aiming for, I've had to push quite a bit to get these answers and should be easier for people in my view.

pros: you get to learn more, helping hands will be available

review_title: Smart people, strong culture .. a bit "noisy" and
pros:
Strong culture of autonomy and independence. Smart people - I especially like the customer- and product-centric attitude in software engineering organisation. Clear mission.

Since the product is growing (both in volumes and complexity due to geographic expansion and new features like the borderless account), the team is also growing rapidly and thus career opportunities are good (either for more responsibility or for leading people). 

While there is a lot of challenging and feedback, it's mostly constructive and warmly presented.

It's certainly the best job I've ever had.
cons:
The independent and autonomous culture can create noise - a lot of opinions and feedback - and this can slow you down or frustrate you, especially if you're a new Product Manafer. Later on, you learn to hear the opinions out and consider them, but ultimately make your own decisions as a product manager.

Some growing pains - as the organisation has grown in size, some aspects of leadership have not scaled quickly enough. This can feel like there's a lack of direction (lack of roadmap that is, the mission is quite clear and reminded often) or lack of clarity in some roles and responsibilities.

Work-life balance can be difficult, since in an independent and autonomous team you're kind of master of your own fate and are expected to create a product much better than the alternatives.

pros: Wonderful company to work for! Great benefits.
cons: Cant name any cons at the time

pros: Flat Structure, Making an actual change, Awesome Team

review_title: Really don't mind waking up in the mornings to head to work in TransferWise. That says it all.
pros:
It is a great company to work for. Positive and inspiring work environment. Very informal work culture with no rules carved in stone. Everything is in constant change and you are the change maker.

The team is fun, youthful, determined and very supportive. Consistent and transparent communication is in practice along with constant feedback. 

The numerous benefits provided by the company contribute to a satisfying work experience. And it's not just about  the free coffee and snacks, it's about the genuine care and attention taken in order to ensure the well-being of every single employee as well as the strong support for enhancing internal relations and team spirit.

One more positive aspect I'd like to point out is the trust and choice of freedom you are given in this company. Whether it's about task-specific decision making or about customizing your job role by choosing your side-projects or specializing in a subject that fascinates you the most.

Very happy for the opportunity given to work together with this like-minded bunch of multinationals.
cons: It's not really a con in a business point of view but since the company is big and constantly growing, it's impossible to know each and every one of the 700 people you're working in the same building with. That's just not something that I'm used to...

review_title: Building a product people love with smart fun people

review_title: Great place to work, although not for everybody.
pros:
You get to work with great people, everybody seems to be very focused on the company's mission and keeping it a great place to work! It might not be everybody as a lot of work you can do is based on your own initiative, definitely not the place for waiting to get a task assigned to you or to sit back and wait for something to happen. 

Lot's of opportunity to develop yourself continuously and are given the room to do so as well, within a fun environment that does cater your well being with healthy breakfast options, massage sessions by professionals, flexible working hours (It's great that I can start at 10 in the morning on any given day or even a bit later when I want to work during evening hours, or vice versa) an environment to tackle your workload to prevent you from burning out.

International travel, not just money without borders but people and teams without borders as well!
cons: Sometimes leadership could step up in areas that need more focus, you have a lot of autonomy and it means that you have to hold yourself accountable to the things that you would like to do, and with that many different options within the company its easy to loose yourself in different areas.

pros: Good culture and human centric teams
cons: Lack of ambition from time to time

review_title: Great culture, not great to get things done
pros:
Really mission driven company that  deeply cares about the customers.
Culture is nice and chill, in product engineering teams you can work in a relaxed manner and only few teams will ever challenge you on this.
cons:
Contrary to the expectations you won't find too many smart good performers around you. TransferWise doesn't compensate in the high brackets to attract those while most original employees with high stock packages have left by now. In addition people in engineering teams are almost never let go so you can imagine what environment this creates for the talent pool. 

Level of technical debt is very high for most teams and it is really hard to develop things quickly. It does not help that leadership team prefers to ignore those problem for most always prioritising features (however minor those are) to long-term fundamental fixing.

review_title: Great culture, great colleagues, great company
pros: TW has an incredible office (very Google-like) with awesome colleagues. Many company events -- two large company outings per year. Plenty of room for growth and no boundaries with wanting to take initiative. Leadership is competent, understanding, and approachable. Free coffee. The work is varied and interesting with plenty of side-projects to take on. Happy and friendly customers. The product is honest so there's no trying to cheat customers -- it's work you can feel good about doing. Plenty of freedom and trust within the company; no one is every breathing over your shoulder. You're treated like a human being.
cons: The work can get intense and burn-outs can come quick if you're not careful. Sometimes you get so into your work you need to be reminded to take a proper lunch break. Salaries are a bit too low and yearly raises are not guaranteed (I think a base for a yearly raise should be established). Not necessarily a con, rather a point of improvement, but cross-team communication can be revamped.

review_title: Exiting place to work with plenty of potential
pros:
TransferWise still holds true to many of it's start up roots, despite having grown as rapidly as it has in such a short period. The opportunity to do meaningful work is up for grab every individual. The company has a strong and clear vision/mission, what is truly excellent is that this vision is inherently good. It's amazing to feel like you are working for the good guys!   
If you have a great idea you can make it happen.
cons: We are growing fast and that can mean some things have been overlooked. Our culture is great at heart and the values we hold are really inspiring, we can have some inconstancy that has appeared with our scale. I have full faith that these inconstancies will be ironed out. Work here can also be intense we say that we are a revolution, this is great to work towards, it's very easy to work too much.

pros:
- there is room to grow, my team lead gives me opportunities to expand my skills and experience, and there is the chance to move to other teams and roles
- you are given a high degree of freedom on projects and in general, as long as you can justify and explain your choices
- as the company is still young and growing, there is plenty of new and interesting projects to work on
- the company has strong, decent values which are actually felt as a big part of the company, and don't just revolve around making money for the company
- company events, summer days in particular, are fantastic
cons:
- it is a very fast paced environment which can be stressful at times 
- having highly autonomous teams can make large distributed projects more difficult and make it harder to focus teams on particular things
- with the very large and quick growth there are sometimes growing pains that go with it

review_title: Amazing Work Culture and great leaders
job_title: Customer Support Agent in Tampa, FL
pros:
Working at TransferWise has been sooooooooo much better than any other job I've had. They actually care about their employees, and I feel a part of a big team. You have a good amount of freedom when it comes to scheduling and the benefits are priced well. Everyone here is very open minded to improving and growing as a company and as a culture. Team leaders are extremely helpful, receptive, and they really do listen to what you have to say. Everyone is empowered to change things i n the company which I really love. 
This job is all about problem solving and days are not boring at all. 
It's got the young start-up mentality of a tech place in California, but its in Tampa!
cons: It can sometimes be very busy, which at times can be stressful, but no where near the stress at other jobs. Scheduling time off needs to be done 30-45 days ahead of time, but there are sick days as well if needed. The pros far outweigh the cons. The pay is enough to live on, but can be a little tight. Not sure what the pay is for promotions but hopefully can get a bit higher.

pros: TransferWise embraces diversity and uniqueness.   This is not your typical corporate environment, so don't expect that. The first place that I have ever worked where Teamwork is not just a word...it is a reality.  Not only does the company listen to the ideas of customers and employees....they implement them when it will make a positive change.
cons: Being a global company with offices in different countries, clear communication can sometimes be challenging.   But...if you are proactive and seek out what you need...there is always someone to help you!

pros:
- Fantastic young, flexible culture to really help you develop (especially coming from a large financial organisation where I was previously)
- Fast-paced, quick moving environment which keeps you on your feet with plenty to do.
- Lots of opportunity to travel (within reason), which coming from an organisation which used to have travel bans, is so refreshing. 
- Great opportunity make an impact to actual customers. The customer is always the mission - and this focus never changes. You feel like you can actually transform a product to help customers. 
- Really good environment to work in. The office is great, people are super friendly and Friday lunch + drinks in London is great.
cons:
- Very young culture (perhaps if you are older - you may struggle to fit in culturally) 
- If you like structure, and process - this place isn't for you
- No real clarity on career development. Not a deal breaker if you are new, but if you are the type of person who likes to have a long term career plan mapped out, you may struggle.

pros: TransferWise is great to gain experience in the banking industry. You learn a lot about rules, regulations, how the money is moved, costs and hang ups. it's a great place to work if you are fairly independent and know what you are doing.
cons:

• Often times I found out that something was my responsibility after the mess was created

job_title: Global Events Project Manager in London, England

pros:
Breakfast in the mornings (cereal, toast, avocadoes), free soda/coffee throughout the day. Team lunch ordered in on Fridays and open bar with beer/wine on Friday evenings. Plenty of events organized such as speakers, yoga sessions, comedy nights, Halloween/Christmas party, summer days are great..

Very open culture, people are friendly.
Strong feedback culture, people will tell you if you're doing something wrong which is great for personal development. They will also tell you if you're doing something right. 
Not hierarchical at all (which isn't ALWAYS a positive when you need someone to do something for you..).
Liberal work from home allowance.
People team cares about the employees.

pros:
- It's BigSmall: It's a big global company with the mindset of a small start-up. Amazing offices, a great name on your CV and the clout to make real change in the world, but with a totally grounded culture and that start-up spirit of always innovating and improving!

- Autonomy: TransferWise has a really unique approach to autonomy; unlike anything I've experienced before.  Rather than telling you what you should be doing, you're encouraged to try and work out yourself how you can best make an impact. This may sound wishy-washy, but the benefits really become apparent over time. You're encouraged to keep questioning, innovating and trying new things. It really allows you to grow as an individual and gives you whatever opportunities you're willing to take.
cons: - Too decentralised?: The autonomous nature of the country can sometimes feel like a double-edged sword; which can mean it takes a long time to get things done or make big decisions. Making change at TransferWise is less about your status, and more about your ability to get democratic support behind your ideas. This can be inefficient, but it also has upsides and is a great life skill to build.

review_title: Dealing with the "good problems to have" in a great culture
pros:

It was hard to understand or believe then. Having been working here now for a few months I have embraced it and already taking it as a norm - something that is usual for me. To understand more about this, you can probably google and find some awesome blog posts about our culture.

Secondly, we are growing. We are growing quite fast. For a dev this gives an awesome opportunity to solve those "good problems" that arise when we need to cater to more and more customers every day. Exciting!

The company values are very well thought through and I can see clearly that we do live by those.
cons:
Open office. I need silence to be able to focus. For this, I have 3 measures, all at the same time:  
1) earplugs 2) active noise cancelling earphones 3) music.

pros:
Onboarding process is very organized and the operations are clearly defined. Currently everybody is working from home, but there is no mess in the operation, as long as I know. 

People are kind, and honest. They are assertive but I have never seen mean people. International, and I don't feel awkward being a foreigner.

Work-life balance is super, especially compared to Japanese companies. lol
cons:
The pay really depends on the regions you are located. They do bench marking time to time, to align the compensation to the regional market. 
I think it's fair enough. My pay is lower than I had before, but I'm very satisfied because of the people, work place, decision making process, and mission itself.

I wonder how HR can hire very talented people without market highest compensation. It's totally opposite of Netflix, I think.
Maybe this is why the culture is warm, and people respect each other. They don't really care who earns like how much. Or never boast for earning more.
